title: 110_s1672
content: The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes the Visual Impairment and Orientation and Mobility Professionals Education Assistance Program under Chapter 80 of title 38, United States Code. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes a scholarship program to provide financial assistance for individuals studying visual impairment or orientation and mobility. The purpose is to increase the supply of qualified blind rehabilitation specialists for the Department and the Nation. The scholarship program established under the VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 aims to increase the supply of qualified blind rehabilitation specialists for the Department and the Nation. The Secretary will publicize the program to educational institutions, with a focus on reaching Hispanic students and Historically Black Colleges and Universities. To apply, individuals must submit an application and agreement for participation, agreeing to serve a period of obligated service in return for educational assistance. The Secretary shall distribute application and agreement forms for the scholarship program, including a summary of rights and liabilities, terms and conditions, and approval notification. The amount of financial assistance provided will cover tuition costs determined by the Secretary. The Secretary determines the amount of financial assistance for tuition and fees under the program. Assistance can supplement other educational aid, but the total assistance for a full-time student cannot exceed $15,000 per academic year. The maximum amount of financial assistance provided under this program is $15,000 per academic year for full-time students and $45,000 in total. Part-time students receive assistance based on the ratio of their coursework to full-time coursework. The duration of assistance is limited to six years. An agreement between the Secretary and participant must be in writing and signed. An agreement between the Secretary and a participant in the scholarship program must be in writing and signed. It includes the Secretary's agreement to provide financial assistance and the participant's agreement to accept the assistance, maintain enrollment, academic standing, and serve as a full-time employee in the Department for three years after completing the program. The agreement between the Secretary and a participant in the scholarship program includes the participant's commitment to serve as a full-time employee in the Department for three years after completing the program. If the individual fails to meet the agreement requirements, they must repay the unearned portion of the educational assistance received. The Secretary will determine the amount of repayment and any exceptions granted. The Secretary will establish procedures for determining repayment amounts and granting exceptions. Waiver or suspension of obligations may be granted in certain circumstances. Repayment to the Secretary is considered a debt to the United States. The Secretary can discharge a person from debt within five years of agreement termination. Clerical amendments are made to title 38. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must implement chapter 80 of title 38, United States Code, within six months of the enactment of this Act.
